a multiline command"?</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8694</link>     <description><pre>Hello list,  with the help of library(magrittr), my code becomes more and more  structured in multiline commands, e.g.:   library(babynames) library(dplyr) library(magrittr) library(ggplot2)  babynames %&gt;%      filter(name %&gt;% substr(1, 3) %&gt;% equals("Ste")) %&gt;%      group_by(year, sex) %&gt;%      summarize(total = sum(n)) %&gt;%      qplot(year, total, color = sex, data = ., geom = "line") %&gt;%      add(ggtitle('Names starting with "Ste"')) %&gt;%      print head(iris)   I am using shift-enter per line, thereby torturing my enter key when  running these long commands. Is there a way for ESS to recognize these 7  lines are one command and run them with only one shift-enter?  I know of ess-eval-region-or-function-or-paragraph-and-step , which  would run that whole thing in one go, but then it would also execute  subsequent commands (the "head(iris)" in above snippet) that are not  separated by a newline.  So ideally, I am looking for a command to bind to shift-enter that would  run the above thing in six hits: one per</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Alexander Engelhardt</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-12T08:11:08</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8690">     <title>remote R</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8690</link>     <description><pre>Hi,  I have two questions about connecting to a remote R session.  (1) What is the state of connecting to a remote R session running in tmux/screen?  (a) control characters in tmux (due to colours?)  I tried ,---- | M-x term | ssh remotemachine | tmux | R | C-c M-x ess-remote `----  This sort of works, but leads to output like this:  ,---- | &gt; [1;40r | [1;39r | &gt; [1;40r | [1;39r | &gt; [1;40r | [0] 0:nios*                                                                                             "farm3-head1" 09:07 06-Mar-15 | [0] 0:nios*                                                                                             "farm3-head1" 09:08 06-Mar-15 | [1;39r | &gt; [1;40r | [1;39r | &gt; [1;40r1+1 | [1;39r1+1 | [1] 2 | &gt; [1;40r | [0] 0:nios*                                                                                             "farm3-head1" 09:09 06-Mar-15library("plyr") | [1;39rlibrary("plyr") | [1;40r[1;39r&gt; [1;40r `----  I guess this is due to my setup somewhere, but before I start digging: Is that </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Andreas Leha</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-06T09:27:12</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8687">     <title>comma in Julia REPL (change-directory, etc)</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8687</link>     <description><pre>Pressing , in the Julia REPL brings up choices for changing the directory etc, but these appear to be unimplemented for Julia.  I would like to implement them, can someone please suggest another language used by ESS that I could use as an example? Perhaps not R, since some functionality (eg vignettes) is not present in Julia so I would need to add/remove features.  Best,  Tamas  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Tamas Papp</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-04T16:10:52</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8686">     <title>Different results in interactive vs batch mode</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8686</link>     <description><pre>Hello ESS helpers,  I have been a happy user of SAS interactive mode for the last few weeks, but have run into something really strange. I wrote some code for data management using proc sql and the data step. I got it working in interactive mode (where "working" means I see the same dataset that my coworker sees independently, using his own programming). However, when I run it in batch mode, the dataset it produces is not right. I did a little poking at it looks like the batch mode version grabs the first "slice" of the data alphabetically, sliced along one of the variables I'm using to merge the datasets, but ignores the remaining 27 slices (i.e. the rows containing other values of this variable).  I could almost understand it if the interactive mode were producing something wrong. But the fact that the batch mode is getting it wrong... that really puzzles me. It happens both when I use the menu SAS-&gt;Submit File and also when I skip emacs and just run it from the command line.  Has anyone ever seen anything</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Erin Jonaitis</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-04T16:05:46</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8682">     <title>Polymode markdown indents (whitespace) lost</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8682</link>     <description><pre>OK to discuss polymode here (apart from ESS?).  In Rmd file for slides, I see problem that lines beginning with dash are pushed to the left margin. I'm writing presentations.  I type this  - pt one     - sub one     -sub two  for nested list.  I usually insert 4 spaces manually, have also tested 2 tabs entry method. In Emacs 24.4 with polymode installed last week, I see problem that the indented lines float back to left side (for no reason I can discern).  Sometimes happens repeatedly, I type space and look back as it disappears.  Have uninstalled polymode and same does not happen, so far as I can tell.  If others don't see same, it means my init file conveniences are causing trouble again, I suppose.  pj Paul Johnson http://pj.freefaculty.org  [[alternative HTML version deleted]]  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul Johnson</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-27T12:46:46</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8680">     <title>how to leverage ESS parsing to find current module in Juliabuffer</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8680</link>     <description><pre>Hi,  I am still working on improving ESS/Julia, especially the evaluation context. The problem I am facing is finding the relevant module for evaluation --- I thought I can simply search backwards with a regexp, but submodules complicate this.  For example, if a buffer contains  --8&lt;---------------cut here---------------start-------------&gt;8--- module Parent  module Child1 f(x) = x+1 end  module Child2 g(x) = x+1                      # eval here end  end --8&lt;---------------cut here---------------end---------------&gt;8---  and the user presses C-c C-c on the line that contains  g(x) = x+1                      # eval here  then the relevant module for eval is Parent.Child2. If I naively search backwards and collect all module lines that match a regexp, I get Parent, Child1, and Child2.  So it seems I would have to parse the file somehow in Emacs. But I notice that ESS already does some of that, since it indents everything correctly. Can I somehow use that to extract a list of open (ie not terminated with an "end"</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Tamas Papp</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-25T09:37:03</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8676">     <title>completion</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8676</link>     <description><pre>Hi all,  I just read the announcement of new completion functionality in RStudio [1].  And there are a few bits that make me jealous, as I do not know how to achieve them is ESS.  Most useful for me would be 1. the completion in dplyrs verbs 2. completion of S3 / S4 methods  Is something like this already feasible without me knowing?  If not, is something similar possible in some not so distant future?  Thanks, Andreas     [1] http://blog.rstudio.org/2015/02/23/rstudio-v0-99-preview-code-completion/  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Andreas Leha</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-24T09:52:35</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8674">     <title>Wrong type argument: numberp, t</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8674</link>     <description><pre>Hello,  I just wrote an email with a bug and I did not add important information I just found.  When I try pasting several lines of code on an R session I get:  "Wrong type argument: numberp, t"  and it only evaluates the first line.  Any help appreciated, Ramiro  p.s. this is my previous email:  I just installed ESS 14.09 on emacs 24.4.  I was using older versions of both previously.  My main issue is that now, after creating an R session, when I copy/paste or try to evaluate several lines of code into it only the first line is evaluated.  What is happening?? Thanks in advance, Ramiro  [[alternative HTML version deleted]]  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Ramiro Barrantes</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-23T19:59:49</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8673">     <title>Only evaluating first line?</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8673</link>     <description><pre>Hello,  I just installed ESS 14.09 on emacs 24.4.  I was using older versions of both previously.  My main issue is that now, after creating an R session, when I copy/paste or try to evaluate several lines of code into it only the first line is evaluated.  What is happening?? Thanks in advance, Ramiro  [[alternative HTML version deleted]]  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Ramiro Barrantes</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-23T19:38:26</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8669">     <title>Inserting Rmd chunk delimiters</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8669</link>     <description><pre>I think it would be nice for Rmd buffers to have an electric-backtick function that auto-inserts the chunk delimiters for R chunks, similar to the way that Rnw files can auto-insert the R chunk delimiters &lt;&lt;&gt;&gt;=   &lt; at &gt;.  In the meantime, I hard-coded ctrl-backtick to insert the delimiters, wrapping the delimiters around the current region if it is active.  I don't really grok lisp, so this code is horrible, but it more or less works.  Improvements would be welcome.  Kevin   (global-set-key (kbd "C-`") 'ess-insert-rmd-chunk)  ; Some code derived from wrap-region ; https://github.com/rejeep/wrap-region.el/blob/master/wrap-region.el (defun ess-insert-rmd-chunk (arg)     "Insert R chunk delimiters"   (interactive "*P")   ;; no region, and blank line   (if (and (not (region-active-p))            (looking-at "[ \ ]*$"))       (let ((pos (point)))             (save-excursion               (insert "```{r}\ \ ```")               (goto-char (+ pos 3) ) ) ) ) ; does NOT move forward.  Why?   ;; region active   (if (region-</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Kevin Wright</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-20T22:42:33</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8667">     <title>improving ESS/julia</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8667</link>     <description><pre>Hi,  I would like to make some improvements to the Julia part of ESS, especially for evaluating code from a buffer (consider modules, have location info for code, etc). I am not an experienced Emacs Lisp programmer and I don't know the internals of ESS, so I would like to ask for some help --- I have some Common Lisp experience. First, I just want to experiment, then submit a PR when https://github.com/emacs-ess/ESS/pull/122 is merged.  My question is the following: for each piece of code that is sent to the inferior process, I would need to wrap it in some Julia code. For example, for evaluating within a module, I would search backward in the buffer for something like "module\\s-\\(\\w.*\\)\\s-" to find the module name, and then send  (concat "eval(" module_name ", :(" string "))")  Which function should I modify for this? ESS-SEND-STRING is not using the buffer any more, and I don't know if I should modify ESS-SEND-REGION.  BTW, what's the best way to use ESS from a git repo? Just add the lisp diretory to the l</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Tamas Papp</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-18T11:43:00</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8662">     <title>/bin/bash markdown : command not found</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8662</link>     <description><pre>Briefly, what are the pieces of the toolchain going from Rmd -&gt; html output?  I'm interested to see what Emacs 24.4 does with markdown. So far as I can find, there's no pre-packaged Emacs 24.4 for Ubuntu 14.10, so I've compiled packages. I have ess working.  The emacs-goodies-el package includes a copy of markdown mode, version 2.0 (2013-03-24).  Now I want to know what is needed to make markdown mode work properly.Is polymode, which I don't yet have installed, going to replace markdown mode?  Right now, I can open an Rmd file in Emacs, M-x markdown-mode, the correct menus appear. However when I try to compile something, I get the minibuffer error /bin/bash: markdown: command not found.  I created a markdown script that expects a command line argument.  #!/bin/bash  R -e "library(markdown); render(\\"$1\\")"  But Emacs-&gt; markdown-mode does not supply the file name argument, so I fail.  PJ   </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul Johnson</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-16T00:09:10</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8649">     <title>ESS[SAS]: Submit region starting new SAS session?</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8649</link>     <description><pre>Hello!  I'm a fairly new emacs user, a very new user of ESS[SAS], and an extremely new subscriber to this list (so apologies if I violate list etiquette). I'm using GNU emacs 23.4.1 (2012-06-05) and SAS 9.3 on Unix (SunOS 5.10).  I have noticed that code which works when submitted as an entire file will not work when I submit it region by region. Here is an example:  libname mylib "/.";  data temp; set mylib.temp; run;  Assume that I have a directory as specified in libname and there is a SAS dataset called temp in it -- my code works properly when I submit the whole thing, but if I run just the first line and then the second, it tells me that "mylib" is not defined.  Based on the behavior of the log files -- the second submission creates a log file that overwrites the first -- I think what is going on is that it's starting a new SAS session with each submission. Why might it be doing this? I find I make fewer programming errors if I test things incrementally rather than running all my code in batch mode, so</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Erin Jonaitis</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-12T17:42:46</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8645">     <title>Macintosh followup advice and question</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8645</link>     <description><pre>I've urged the students to try Emacs on Mac and Dr Goulet's installer works very well.   In the process, I've learned a couple of things. I wonder if these messages should be conveyed to users more bluntly  1. It is VITAL to go into the Mac's Mission Control and change the shortcut keys.  THey are currently using Control-up arrow and Control-down arrow as window manager things, and if you don't free up those shortcuts, your like in the R console is empty, without any joy whatsoever.  This seems like such a vital piece of advice that it should be plainly stated somewhere on the "R for mac users".  Advice sheets I find generally assume a user likes Macs and Emacs and neither is true for most of these users, they just want to know what to do.  2. Also we need to say "XQuartz" is a mandatory install, there's no point having R without it.   Now, my question.  3. In Emacs Mac, How do you save the output from *R* as a text file?  I told the users to just save the *R* window with File-&gt;save as and give the file the </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul Johnson</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-09T17:34:13</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8644">     <title>[OT] New Emacs Modified version</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8644</link>     <description><pre>Please note that I updated my Emacs Modified distributions for OS X and Windows earlier this week.   http://vgoulet.act.ulaval.ca/en/emacs  From the NEWS file:  Version 24.4-modified-2 (2 February 2015) =========================================  UPDATES  o AUCTeX 11.88  and additionally, on Windows:  NEW FEATURES  o GnuTLS libraries are now included to allow Emacs to access web sites   using https; see      http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17219643/cant-install-emacs-el-get-package-emacs-cant-connect-to-the-internet    for a rationale. Thanks to Emiliano Heyns &lt;emiliano.heyns&lt; at &gt;iris-advies.com&gt;   for the suggestion.  USER VISIBLE CHANGES  o The distribution version string is now included in the   README-Modified.txt file.  BUG FIXES  o The site-start.d directory was incorrectly located in the previous   release.  o Files were inadvertently left in the installation directory.  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Vincent Goulet</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-05T19:08:48</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8637">     <title>Problem with (setq ess-help-own-frame t) : emacs answers that "ess--switch-to-help-buffer: Window is dedicated to `*help[R](geom_line)*'</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8637</link>     <description><pre>Dear list,  I wanted to have a different frame for each request to R help. so i used (setq ess-help-own-frame t) in my .emacs.  I have a problem : the first call ("?geom_line" at the R prompt) works fine, but a second call ("?geom_linerange" at the R prompt) ends up in error with "ess--switch-to-help-buffer: Window is dedicated to `*help[R](geom_line)*' in the minibuffer (retrieved form the *Messages* buffer).  (setq ess-help-own-frame 'one) works as advertised. The code (in ess-help.el) is not specially enlightening : it uses *ONE* frame, defined in (defvar ess-help-frame ...). So it appears that the code *is* intended to display exactly *one* help page at a time, with two variants : - switching to the last requested help page when ess-help_own-frame is 'one - raising an error when ess-help-own-frame is t and the ess-help-frame still exists.  Do you see a way to effect what I *thought* was advertised : at each call to the R help system, open (if necessary) a new frame to display the relevant help page ?  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Emmanuel Charpentier</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-01-25T10:15:56</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8625">     <title>Mac OSX 10.10.1 Yosemite can't find R</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8625</link>     <description><pre>This system  Student in my office now showing me Emacs with ESS (From Vincent Goulet's website) and when we open an R file, all seems well.  Hit the big blue R Searching for program: No such file or directory, R  Preliminary googling indicates Yosemite has done something to change the PATH or the way R is in the PATH (or not).  If you are a Mac user, can you please tell me the most direct/safest/best way to deal with this.  So far, I see suggestion to set PATH in ~/.bashrc or to fiddle about in the Emacs init.el file.  pj   </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul Johnson</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-01-22T20:07:15</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8623">     <title>ESS + Stata: Getting indentation right in Stata-mode editor</title>     <link>http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8623</link>     <description><pre>I've noticed that indentation in Stata-mode doesn't quite work right in ESS. For comments /* */ at the end of lines or after the continuation sequence /// subsequent lines indent indefinitely. For code of more than 2 lines, this can get very nested looking (see below):  recode educ 0 = 1 ///     5 = 2 ///         10 = 3 ///             15 = 4 ///                 20 = 5 ///                     25 = 6  Is there a workaround for this? I *really* like running Stata through ESS and would love to use it this way as much as I can.  For now, I've been editing in Bill Rising's ado mode and sending to Stata through ESS. The drawback to this approach is that every time I open a new do file (which I do often to edit single lines here and there for a big project), I have to indicate which dialect of ESS I am using in the buffer line.
